question:
Directions:

Directions : Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions that follow.

Worldwide, at least 13% of people between the ages of 10 and 19 live with a diagnosed mental health disorder, according to the latest State of the World's Children report, published by the United Nations Children's charity UNICEF. It is the first time in the organisation's history that this flagship report has tackled the challenges and opportunities for preventing and treating mental health problems among young people. It reveals that adolescent mental health is highly complex, understudied, and underfunded. Anxiety and depression constitute more than 40% of mental health disorders among young people (those aged 10 - 19).

UNICEF also reports that, worldwide, suicide is the fourth most common cause of death (after road injuries, tuberculosis and interpersonal violence) among adolescents (aged 15 - 19). Sadly, psychological distress among young people seems to be rising. There is also initial evidence that the coronavirus pandemic is exacerbating this trend in some countries. Although most mental health disorders arise during adolescence, UNICEF says that only one-third of investment in mental health research is targeted towards young people. Moreover, the research itself suffers from fragmentation- scientists involved tend to work inside some key disciplines, such as psychiatry, paediatrics, psychology and epidemiology, and the links between research and healthcare services are often poor.

By contrast, researchers have found that improving young people's cognitive and interpersonal skills can be more effective in preventing and treating anxiety and depression under certain circumstances - although the reason for this is not known. For instance, a concept known as 'decentring' or 'psychological distancing' (that is, encouraging a person to adopt an objective perspective on negative thoughts and feelings) can help both to prevent and to alleviate depression and anxiety, although the underlying neurobiological mechanisms are unclear.

In addition, the Campbell Family Mental Health Institute in Toronto, Canada reported a meta-analysis of 90 randomised controlled trials. They found that helping young people improve their emotion-regulation skills, which are needed to control emotional responses to difficult situations, enables them to cope better with anxiety and depression. However, it is still unclear whether better regulation of emotions is the cause or the effect of these improvements.



According to the UNICEF report, what is the primary characteristic of the current state of research on adolescent mental health?
option_1: The studies are comprehensive and adequately funded.
option_2: The ongoing analysis suffers academic neglect and lacks financial support.
option_3: The work is limited to key disciplines with strong links to healthcare.
option_4: The studies focus on prevention more than treatment.
option_5: An inclusive understanding of treatment outcomes is reflected in the research.
solution:
The first paragraph of the passage mentions, "It is the first time in the organisation's history that this flagship report has tackled the challenges..It reveals that adolescent mental health is highly complex, understudied, and underfunded." It can be understood from the given reference that academic neglect and insufficient financial aid characterise the current research on adolescent mental health.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b).

Select the antonym of the word 'alleviate' that is emboldened in the passage.
solution:
Ameliorate: To make a situation, condition, or outcome better or more favourable; to improve.

Mitigate: To make a situation or consequence less severe, harmful, or painful.

Integrate: To combine or unify different elements into a whole; to bring them together.

Effectuate: To bring about or achieve a desired result; to make something happen or become effective.

Aggravate: To make a situation, condition, or problem more severe, intense, or irritating; to worsen.

Alleviate: To make a burden, pain, or hardship less severe; to relieve or ease a situation or condition.

Among the given options, the word 'aggravate' is opposite in meaning of the word 'alleviate'. So, the two words can be used as antonyms of each other.

Hence, the correct answer is option (e).

question:
Directions:

Directions : In the questions given below, a set of sentences is given, which when properly sequenced, forms a coherent paragraph. Arrange the sentences in the correct sequence and answer the questions that follow.

A. In the view of Downing Street, it is an intolerable affront to national sovereignty to have EU rulings applicable anywhere on UK territory under any circumstances.

B. The demand of Mr. Frost amounts to, in essence, detonating the foundations of the deal.

C. The court is intrinsic to the operation of single-market rules, which apply in Northern Ireland to avoid the requirement for a hard border with the Republic of Ireland.

D. To make it the day before the European Commission was due to propose its own technical remedies to operational problems with the protocol was downright provocative.

E. The EU is offering a high degree of flexibility in customs enforcement and regulatory checks, effectively applying a lot more benefit of the doubt so that many more goods can cross from Britain to Northern Ireland unimpeded.



Which of the following is the THIRD rearranged sentence?
solution:
The correct order is CBADE.

The sentence C introduces the topic of discussion - single-market rules and hence is the introductory statement. B immediately follows by stating the contradictory political scenario to the single-market rules. The consecutive sentence A further extends the contradiction offered by B. D tries to validate the argument of A-B by providing a context and opining the consequence. E provides information that can be an evidence for an alternative method that neutralises the contradictions in the preceding statements.


A is the third rearranged sentence and option a) is the correct answer.

question:
In the following question, match the statement from Column 1 with Column 2 and find which of the following pair/s of statements given in the options is/are contextually and grammatically correct.

COLUMN 1COLUMN 2
A. Spring is my favourite season because at that timeD. the streets are filled with leaves fallen from trees which make the roads appear colourful.
B. I am not much into music, but when I rarely do listen toE. songs, I listen to classic songs from the era of 90s when I was a kid.
C. Mac and Cheese is an Italian dish that's although delicious but it is alsoF. extremely unhealthy at the same time as it can severely clog your blood vessels with all that fat.
solution:
The correctly matched pairs are: A-D, B-E, C-F

A-D - Statement A talks about spring being the speaker's favourite season and the reason is stated in statement D as 'the streets are filled with leaves fallen from trees which make the roads appear colourful'.

B-E - Statement B talks about a person not listening much to music and rarely playing songs, which is matched by 'I listen to classic songs from the era of 90s' from statement E.

C-F - Statement C describes 'Mac and Cheese' as a delicious dish, which is matched by 'extremely unhealthy at the same time as it can severely clog your blood vessels' from statement F.

Hence, the correct answer is option (d).

question:
In the question given below, a sentence is given with two blanks, followed by five options. From the given options, choose the one that gives the correct set of words fitting the blanks.

The villagers gathered around the ancient ______, preparing for the annual sacrificial ceremony to ______ the gods.
solution:
The first blank needs a noun because a specific object is being described, indicating its age and significance. The adjective "ancient" precedes the first blank so a noun denoting an old and ancient object/place would fill the blank. 'Altar', which means 'a usually raised structure or place on which sacrifices are offered or incense is burned in worship' is a contextual fit for the first blank. The second blank requires a verb because it's describing an action that the villagers are performing in relation to the gods. The word "appease" is a verb which means to satisfy or calm, which fits perfectly in the context of the sentence. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

The final sentence: The villagers gathered around the ancient altar, preparing for the annual sacrificial ceremony to appease the gods.

The rest of the options are not suitable because either they don't fit contextually or they are not the appropriate part of the speech to be filled in the blanks.

Alter - To change something in some way. (verb) This part of speech doesn't fit in the first blank.

Applaud - To clap your hands to show approval or appreciation. (verb)

Mausoleum - An impressive building above or below ground where a dead person's body is buried. (noun) This doesn't fit in the first blank contextually.

Wickedness - Evil or cruelty. (noun) This doesn't fit in the first blank contextually.

Hurl - To throw something with force. (verb)

Bombardment - a continuous attack with bombs, shells, or other missiles. (noun) This part of speech doesn't fit in the second blank.

question:
In the question given below, a sentence is given with two blanks, followed by five options. From the given options, choose the one that gives the correct set of words fitting the blanks.

The _____ between science fiction and fantasy genres often results in imaginative worlds filled with ______ magic.
solution:
The first blank requires a noun. The sentence discusses a relationship or connection between two genres: science fiction and fantasy. Therefore, we need a noun that describes this connection or interaction. The word "crossover" fits well here because it implies a blending or crossing over of elements from both genres.

The second blank requires an adjective to describe the kind of worlds created as a result of this relationship between science fiction and fantasy. The adjective "futuristic" fits best because it suggests advanced or imaginative elements, like those often found in science fiction and fantasy settings.

Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

The final sentence: The crossover between science fiction and fantasy genres often results in imaginative worlds filled with futuristic magic.

The rest of the options are not suitable because either they don't fit contextually or they are not the appropriate part of the speech to be filled in the blanks.

"Morale" (noun) refers to the confidence, enthusiasm, or spirit of a group. This doesn't fit in the first blank contextually.

"Riots" (noun) refer to violent disturbances by a crowd. This doesn't fit in the first blank contextually.

"Amused" (verb) means entertained or finding something funny. This part of speech is unfit for the second blank.

"Restoration" (noun) refers to the act of bringing something back to its original condition. This doesn't fit in the first blank contextually.

"Spacious" (adjective) means having a lot of space or room.

question:
In the question below, a sentence is given with two words missing. You are given five options each containing a pair of words that can or cannot fill the blanks grammatically and/or contextually. Identify the words that are opposite in meaning to each other and make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct.

The curator ______ us through the gallery, and we ______ him quietly, observing the masterpieces with great interest.
solution:
'Guided' and 'followed' are opposite in meaning to each other and correctly fill the blanks. The sentence conveys that the narrator followed the curator (a person whose job is to look after the things that are kept in a museum) in the museum.

Options A and D are eliminated as the pairs of antonyms do not grammatically fit in the blanks. The blanks require verbs to describe the actions of both curator and the narrator (a part of 'we') respectively. But these options contain adjectives. Options B and E are eliminated as the words are unrelated in meaning.

Hence, the answer is option C.

question:
In the question below, a sentence is given with two words missing. You are given five options each containing a pair of words that can or cannot fill the blanks grammatically and/or contextually. Identify the words that are opposite in meaning to each other and make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct.

Troops were sent to _____ the people who were _____ by the dictator.
solution:
'Liberate' and 'confined' are opposite in meaning to each other and correctly fill the blanks. 'Liberate' means 'to allow somebody/something to be free'; 'confined' means 'held captive'. The sentence conveys that the troops were sent to free the people from the dictator's capture.

Option A is eliminated as the pair of antonyms does not contextually relate to 'troops' and 'dictator'. Option B is eliminated as the word 'despondency' does not grammatically fit in the second blank. The blank requires a verb to describe the action of the dictator, but 'despondency' is a noun. Options C and D are eliminated as the words are unrelated in meaning.

Hence, the answer is option E.

question: In the question given below, one part of the sentence may have an error. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If the sentence is free from error, select 'No error'. Ignore errors of punctuation, if any.
solution: The error is in 4 since an inappropriate preposition has followed the verb 'spend'. When the question concerns spending one's money, time, energy, etc., 'spend' is always followed by the preposition 'on', not 'for'. 'Spend' is an irregular verb because its past tense and the past participle are irregular formed. So 'spent' doubles as the past tense and past participle of 'spend'. The correction is.. 'to spend on luxuries'.

question: In the question given below, one part of the sentence may have an error. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If the sentence is free from error, select 'No error'. Ignore errors of punctuation, if any.
solution: Imply means to suggest and thus is incorrect. We can 'conclude' or 'derive' or 'infer' from the facts.

question:
In the given question, a word has been given and there are three ways in which the word has been used, in similar or different forms. Find out which of the sentences has/have correctly used the highlighted word and mark your answer accordingly.

Balloon

I. He let the air out of the balloon.

II. He warned that the deficit may continue to balloon.

III. I love the balloon taste of limes.
solution:
The word "balloon" can be used in different contexts and with different meanings. Primarily, it refers to an inflatable object typically made of rubber or latex, designed to be filled with air or gas, often for decorative purposes or as a means of aerial transportation. Figuratively, "balloon" can describe something expanding rapidly or uncontrollably.

In sentence I, "balloon" is used correctly as a noun referring to an inflatable object often filled with air or gas for decoration or amusement.

In sentence II, "balloon" is used metaphorically to describe the potential rapid increase or expansion of the deficit. This usage is correct and appropriate.

Sentence III uses "balloon" incorrectly. The intended meaning is to describe the taste of limes as sour, but "balloon" does not fit in this context. A more appropriate word would be "sour" to convey the taste of limes accurately. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

question: In the question given below, one part of the sentence may or may not have an error. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If the sentence is free from error, select 'No error'. Ignore punctuation errors, if any.
solution: The error is in part b) of the given sentence. The is related to the use of reflexive pronoun 'myself'; according to the rules of English grammar, we do not use a reflexive pronoun after verbs which describe things people usually do for themselves, such as wash, shave, dress; hence, to make the sentence correct myself should be omitted. Hence the answer is option b).

question: In the question given below, one part of the sentence may have an error. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If the sentence is free from error, select 'No error'. Ignore errors of punctuation, if any.
solution: When we join the nouns with neither nor, we match the pronoun with the last noun in the list. In this case last noun is Raman and thus "their" should be replaced with "his". Hence, option (c) is the answer.

question:
A sentence is given in which certain words are highlighted. Choose the option with the pair/s of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically correct and meaningful. If no change is required, mark E as your response.

A comprehensive (A) energy policy is necessary as the country is unable to order (B) even half of the total installed capacity and several areas continue (C) to reel under darkness (D) with power cuts becoming the utilize (E) of the day.
solution: At (E), we need a noun (or an adjective followed by a noun) as it is preceded by an article. 'Order' is suitable here, as 'the order of the day' means 'the prevailing custom or state of affairs'. 'Utilize' can be used at (B), to make the sentence mean that the installed power capacity is not being utilized well by the country. Option B is the right answer.

question:
A sentence is given in which certain words are highlighted. Choose the option with the pair/s of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically correct and meaningful. If no change is required, mark E as your response.

Few organised sector despite (A) get generated in India because industries prefer(B) capital-intensive production jobs (C) the economy's relative abundance(D) of low-wage labour(E).
solution: Clearly, 'despite' is a misfit at (A). We needed a noun here, but 'despite' is a preposition. 'Jobs' is the correct word to be used at (A). 'Despite' can be used at (C) to tell us that industries prefer capital-intensive production over low-wage labour. Option C is the right answer.

question:

question:
Match the statements from column 1 with column 2 and find which of the following pairs of statements given in the options make/s contextually and grammatically correct sense.

Column 1Column 2
A. Early criminologists in the U.S. and Europe seriously debatedD. and they must does more to stop this practice, as well as reporting it to the police.
B. Knives can be purchased on Facebook Marketplace without age verificationE. whether criminals have certain identifying facial features separating them from non-criminals.
C. It is totally unacceptable for social media companies to allow the illegal sale of weapons on their platformsF. despite of a recent law requiring checks.
solution: The correct answer is option c). 'A' is about 'early criminologists debated about something' and 'E' completes it by saying 'whether criminals have certain identifying facial features separating them from non-criminals.' So, the sentence is about debate among early criminologist, whether criminals have certain identifying features which separate them from non-criminals.' D- a plural subject 'they' will take a plural verb 'do' and not 'does'; hence, is grammatically incorrect. F- incorrect phrase 'despite of' ('despite' isn't followed by preposition 'of').

question:
In the given question, a word has been given and there are three ways in which the word has been used, in similar or different forms. You need to see which of the sentences has/have correctly used the highlighted word, and mark that as your answer.

Idol

I. Many young musicians consider him their idol and aspire to follow in his footsteps.

II. The villagers placed an idol in the temple and performed daily rituals.

III. She idoled her teacher so much that she imitated everything she did.
solution:
The word "idol" has different meanings based on context:

Sentence I: Correct usage, as "idol" refers to a person admired greatly.

Sentence II: Correct usage, as "idol" refers to a religious statue or image.

Sentence III: Incorrect usage, as "idoled" is not a correct verb form. Instead, "idolized" should be used.

Since only sentences I and II correctly use "idol," the correct answer is option (d).

question:
In the given question, a word has been given and there are three ways in which the word has been used, in similar or different forms. You need to see which of the sentences has/have correctly used the highlighted word, and mark that as your answer.

Sustain

I. The bridge was built to sustain heavy loads without collapsing.

II. She could not sustain her interest in the course and eventually dropped out.

III. The company sustained huge profits due to increased sales.
solution:
The word "sustain" has different meanings based on context:

Sentence I: Correct usage, as "sustain" means to support or bear weight.

Sentence II: Correct usage, as "sustain" means to continue or maintain something over time.

Sentence III: Incorrect usage, as "sustained" does not mean "earned" or "gained." "Sustain" in the sense of "suffered or experienced" is usually used with negative outcomes (e.g., sustained losses/injuries). "Achieved" or "earned" would be a better word choice here.

Since only sentences I and II correctly use "sustain," the correct answer is option (c).

question: In the question given below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Select the one that is grammatically and contextually correct.
option_1: The two skippers had quite a bit of banter in the middle, so much so that they almost made physical contact at one point.
option_2: But Australian skipper shrugged it of, saying that Australia will invite India for a beer in the change rooms as per their team tradition.
option_3: There's a lot in the line and both teams desperately want to win.
option_4: But the wicketkeeper-batsman was quick to assert that he won't backed down in the face of a showdown if it happens again.
solution:
B - The correct phrase is 'shrug off' which means to ignore something so 'of' should be replaced with 'off'. C - The phrase 'on the line' means at serious risk so 'in' must be replaced with 'on'. D - We use the base form of the verb after a modal verb (won't); 'back' should be used in place of 'backed'.

A is grammatically correct and meaningful. Hence, option A is the correct answer.

question:
In the following question, a word has been given and there are three ways in which the word has been used- in similar or different forms. Find out which of the following sentences has/have correctly used the given word and mark your answer accordingly.

Inequality

I. According to socialists, inequality is the worst blasphemy against the sanctity of humanity.

II. Yet the roots of inequality in the modern world lie far back in prehistory.

III. His young cousin admired Henri's passion for action and rejection of inequality.
solution: 'Inequality(noun)' means 'difference in size, degree, circumstances, etc.; lack of equality'. It is also defined as the state of not being equal, especially in status, rights, and opportunities. All the three sentences have used the word in a grammatically and contextually correct way. Option C is the correct answer.

question: In the question given below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Select the one that is grammatically and contextually correct.
option_1: In order to fully understand your organization's trajectory and the needs and expectations of your customers, its best to determine exactly who/what your competition is.
option_2: Allegations of widespread fraud concerning generic drugs manufactured overseas, especially in China, were recently highlighted in the U.S.
option_3: A SC bench has being directed state administration to hand over illegally extracted coal to Coal India Limited (CIL) which will auction it and deposit the funds with state government.
option_4: Each year more than 50 lakh babies is born with genetic disease in India, most of which are presently untreatable and for those that can be treated, treatment is very expensive.
solution: (a) is incorrect because of usage of the possessive determiner 'its' which should instead be replaced with the contraction 'it's'. (c) is incorrect because the use of 'being' is redundant here, so it must be eliminated from the sentence. (d) is incorrect because the subject in consideration (babies) is plural, so it should be followed by the plural auxiliary verb 'are' instead of 'is'. (b) is grammatically correct and meaningful, so option (b) is the correct answer.

question: In the question given below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Select the one that is grammatically and contextually incorrect.
option_1: Since nearly 30 years, women's share of the global labour force has been stuck stubbornly around the 39% mark.
option_2: The glacial progress toward gender equality in work is evident from the low percentage of women in global labour force.
option_3: Progress toward gender equality in work is glacial and the fact that women's share of the global labour force has been about 39% for past 30 years clearly corroborates it.
option_4: Owing to a mere 39% share of women in the global labour force for past 30 years we can surely say that gender equality in work is still a far-fetched idea.
solution: In sentence a), the usage of 'since' is incorrect; here, we refer to a period of 30 years; 'since' is used to indicate the beginning of a time period until the present; hence, should not be used here. 'For' is used when talking about an amount of time - how long something happens; usually, it is used to denote a period of time. Other sentences are grammatically and contextually correct. Hence, the answer is option a).

question:
In the question below, a sentence is given with five words highlighted in bold. One or more than one of these five words may either be wrongly spelt or inappropriate in the context of the sentence. Find out the word(s), which is/are wrongly spelt or inappropriate, if any.

Smith was asked to surender(A) his officer badge(B)until he proved his innocense(C) in the case(D) for which he was arrested(E).
solution:
In the sentence, the word 'innocence' is incorrectly spelt as 'innocense' and also the word 'surrender' is incorrectly spelt as 'surender'. 'Innocence' means 'the state, quality, or fact of being innocent of a crime or offence' and 'surrender' means 'to stop resisting an enemy or opponent and submit to their authority'.

question:

The militant(A) group is irked(B) against the present precedent(C) who strongly condemns(D) the activities(E) of such groups.
solution:
In the sentence the word 'precedent' (means 'an official action or decision that has happened in the past and that is considered as an example or rule to follow in the same situation later') is a noun which is used in the place of the noun 'president'. The word 'precedent' is contextually inappropriate to the sentence. It is grammatically incorrect as well because the pronoun 'who' is used for humans ('president' in case of this sentence). Remaining highlighted words are appropriate.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b).

He gestured(A) towards the crenellated (B) walls of Simena Castle, riding(C) up a ruged (D) ridje (E).
solution:
Words D and E are incorrectly spelt. The correct spellings of the respective words are 'rugged' (having a broken, rocky, and uneven surface) and 'ridge' (a long, narrow hilltop, mountain range, or watershed).

Crenellated- (of a wall or building) having battlements.

Hence, the correct answer is option (e).

question: A train of length approximately 901 meters crosses a person running in opposite direction in approximately 43.199 seconds and time taken by same train to cross the same person when running in same direction (with the same speed) is 72 seconds, then what is the time taken by train to cross a platform of length 150 meters?
solution:
Let speed of train and speed of person is 'x' km/h and 'y' km/h respectively.

Effective speed of train and person when running in opposite direction = (x + y) km/h

Effective speed of train and person when running in same direction = (x - y) km/h

Now,

901 = (x + y) * 43.199 * (5/18)

900 = (x + y) * 43.2 * (5/18)

(x + y) = 75 ..... (1)

901 = (x - y) * 72 * (5/18)

(x - y) = 45 ..... (2)

From (1) and (2):

x = 60 km/h and y = 15 km/h

Let time taken by train to cross a platform of length 150 meters = 't' seconds

Now,

(901 + 150) = 60 * t * (5/18)

(900 + 150) = 60 * t * (5/18)

1050 = 60 * t * (5/18)

t = 63 seconds

question: A committee of 5 members is to be made from 9 men and 3 women. Find the probability that the committee has at least two women.
solution:
The total number of ways of selection = 12C5 = 12*11*10*9*8*7! /5*4*3*2*7!

= 11*9*8

The number of ways of selection = 3C2 * 9C3 + 3C3 * 9C2

= (3*2! /1*2!) * (9*8*7*6! /3*2*6!) + (1) * (9*8*7! /2*7!)

= 3 * 3*4*7 + 9 *4

= 252 + 36 = 288

The required probability = 288/ 11 * 9 * 8 = 4/11

question: The ratio of the perimeter of the rectangle to the length of the rectangle is 22: 7. If the area of the rectangle is X cm2 and the breadth of the rectangle is 15 cm less than its length, then find the value of X.
solution:
Let the length of the rectangle be 'a' cm.

Breadth = a - 15 cm

The perimeter of the rectangle = 2 * (L + B)

A/Q

[2 * (a + a - 15)]/ a = 22/7

7 [4a - 30] = 22a

28a - 210 = 22a

6a = 210

a = 35

Breadth = 35 - 15 = 20 cm

The area of the rectangle = Length * Breadth

Hence, X = 35 * 20 = 700

question:
In the following question, two statements numbered I and II are given. On solving them, we get quantities I and II respectively. Compare the numeric value of both the quantities and choose the correct option.

A sold a wristwatch to B at 10% profit and B sold it to C at 2420 at 12% loss.

Quantity I: 12% of cost price of wristwatch for A.

Quantity II: 10% of cost price of wristwatch for B.
option_5: Quantity I = Quantity II or a relation can't be established
solution:
Cost price of wristwatch for A = a

Cost price of wristwatch for B = 1.1a

Cost price of wristwatch for C = 1.1a * 0.88 = 0.968a

0.968a = 2420

a = 2500

Quantity I: 12% of cost price of wristwatch for A = (12/100) * 2500 = 300

Quantity II: 10% of cost price of wristwatch for B = (10 * 1.1 * 2500)/100 = 275

Quantity I > Quantity II

Hence, option a is correct.

question:
The question contains a statement followed by two quantities. Read the following information carefully and answer your question accordingly.

Quantity I:A and B enter into a partnership with investment in the ratio 8: 5 respectively. After one-year partnership, A got Rs.450 more than B as profit. What is the total profit earned by them?

Quantity II:What is the simple interest on Rs.3900 at 25% per annum in 3 years?
solution:
From quantity I:

Investment period for A and B is same i.e., one-year. So,

Profit ratio = investment ratio, A: B = 8: 5

Total profit earned by A and B together = 450 * (8 + 5)/(8 - 5) = Rs.1950

From quantity II:

Simple interest on Rs.3900 at 25% per annum in 2 years = 3900 * 25 * 3/100 = Rs.2925

Hence, Quantity I < Quantity II

question: The difference between simple interest earned on a sum of money at 21% rate of interest after 3 years and the compound interest earned on the same sum of money at 20% rate of interest after 2 years is 7600. Find the amount invested in simple interest?
solution:
Let the principal = P

Simple interest earned at 21% rate of interest after 3 years = P(1 + 3*21/100) = 163P/100

Compound interest earned at 20% rate of interest after 2 years = P(1 + 20/100)2 = 144P/100

Difference between simple and compound interest = 7600

163P/100 - 144P/100 = 7600

P = 760000/19

P = 40000

question: The average of four numbers is 560 and the ratio of second and first numbers is 2: 1 and the ratio of third and fourth numbers is 2: 3. If the third number is 33(1/3)% of the second number, then what is the sum of the first and third number?
solution:
The ratio of second and first number is 2: 1, and third and fourth number is 2: 3 respectively

third number is 33(1/3)% of the second number

=> (third number)/(second number) = 1/3

So, ratio of share of first, second, third and fourth numbers = 3: 6: 2: 3

Let first number = 3x, second number = 6x, third number = 2x and fourth number = 3x

3x + 6x + 2x + 3x = 560 * 4

=> 14x = 2240

=> x = 160

So, sum = 3x + 2x = 5x = 5 * 160 = 800

question:

Directions : The hexagonal-shaped ground has six entry gates which are numbered as 1 to 6 in the clockwise direction. The distance between two adjacent gates is the same. The different numbers of contestants viz., 21, 32, 54, 75, 85 and 92 stand on each gate for the Indian Idol audition, but not necessarily in the same order.

139 contestants stand between Gate 1 and Gate 4. 54 and 32 contestants stand on the adjacent gates. 75 contestants stand on Gate 6. 92 contestants neither stand on Gate 1 nor Gate 4. The total number of contestants standing on Gate 6 and Gate 4 is four less than the square of the smallest two-digit number.



Which among the following gates has the lowest number of contestants?
solution:
The hexagonal-shaped ground has six entry gates which are numbered as 1 to 6 in the clockwise direction. The distance between two adjacent gates is the same.

139 contestants stand between Gate 1 and Gate 4.

From the given data, 85 contestants + 54 contestants = 139 contestants.

75 contestants stand on Gate 6. So, case 2 and 2a cancelled.

54 and 32 contestants stand on the adjacent gates.

92 contestants neither stand on Gate 1 nor Gate 4.

So, 92 contestants stand on Gate 5 and 21 contestants stand either on Gate 1 or Gate 4.

The total number of contestants standing on Gate 6 and Gate 4 is four less than the square of the smallest two-digit number.

The total number of contestants standing on Gate 6 and Gate 4 is:

For case 1= 75+32=107

For case 1a= 75+21= 96

10 is the smallest two digit number. Its square is 100.

So, this condition satisfies only in case 1a.

So, the final solution is:


Gate 4 has the lowest number of contestants i.e., 21 contestants.

question: In a class of 71 students, Kiran is ranked exactly between Rao and Fiza. If Kiran and Fiza interchange their positions, then Kiran is ranked 56th from the start of the ranking and only five students will be ranked after Rao. What is the rank of Fiza from the end of the ranking?
solution:
In a class of 71 students, Kiran is ranked exactly between Rao and Fiza.

Case 1Start of rankingRao'n' StudentsKiran'n' StudentsFizaEnd of ranking
Case 2Start of rankingFiza'n' StudentsKiran'n' StudentsRaoEnd of ranking

If Kiran and Fiza interchange their positions, then Kiran is ranked 56th from the start of the ranking.

Case 1Start of rankingRao'n' StudentsFiza'n' StudentsKiran 56thEnd of ranking
Case 2Start of rankingKiran 56th'n' StudentsFiza'n' StudentsRaoEnd of ranking

Only 5 students will be ranked after Rao. Thus, case 1 is invalid.

Case 2Start of rankingKiran 56th'n' StudentsFiza'n' StudentsRao5 studentsEnd of ranking

Thus, we get:

Start of rankingKiran 56th4 StudentsFiza4 StudentsRao5 studentsEnd of ranking

So, Fiza is ranked 11th from the end.

The trucks are P, Q, R, S, T, U, V and W and they are carrying different goods among Livestock, Concrete, Steel, Fruits, Timber, Coal, Petrol and Water.

The truck carrying petrol is opposite to the truck carrying steel. Truck R is parked opposite to the truck carrying timber. Truck T is parked at the end of the row and is carrying either water or fruits. Q is parked second to the left of V. Truck S is carrying concrete. The truck adjacent to the truck opposite to V is carrying fruits. Q is parked at the end of the row and is opposite to the truck carrying coal. Truck P is carrying steel and is not in the same row as Q. The truck carrying livestock is opposite to the truck W. Truck carrying timber is in the row facing the north. The trucks carrying coal and water are adjacent to each other.



Select the odd one out.
solution:
It is given that,

The trucks are P, Q, R, S, T, U, V and W.

The trucks are carrying different goods among Livestock, Concrete, Steel, Fruits, Timber, Coal, Petrol and Water.

Q is parked at the end of the row and is opposite to the truck carrying coal.

Q is parked second to the left of V.

The trucks carrying coal and water are adjacent to each other.

We get,

The truck adjacent to the truck opposite to V is carrying fruits.

Truck P is carrying steel and is not in the same row as Q.

The truck carrying petrol is opposite to the truck carrying steel.

We get,

Truck carrying timber is in the row facing the north.

Here, case 1 is invalid.

Truck R is parked opposite to the truck carrying timber.

We get,

Truck S is carrying concrete.

The truck carrying livestock is opposite to the truck W.

We get,

Truck T is parked at the end of the row and is carrying either water or fruits.

Here, case 2.1 is invalid.

The final arrangement is,


Only the truck carrying water is not at the end of the row.

question:
Directions:

Directions : In a family of seven members- P, Q, R, S, T, U and V either none or both parents are alive. S, who is the sister of Q, is married to T. Q is the son of P. R and V are granddaughters of P. U is the father-in-law of T.



How is R related to T?
solution:
S, who is the sister of Q, is married to T.

Q is the son of P.

U is the father-in-law of T.

R and V are granddaughters of P.

A family of seven members and either none or both parents are alive.

Thus, R and V are daughters of S.

Therefore, the final arrangement is:


R is the daughter of T.
